mischief.translation[0].definitions[0].d: bad behaviour, especially by children, that causes trouble or damage, but no serious harm
mischief.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Now run along, and don’t get into mischief.
They’ve got enough toys to keep them out of mischief for a while.
If you can’t see Nick, you can be sure he’s up to some mischief  (=behaving badly and causing trouble or damage).
mischief.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the pleasure or enjoyment of playing tricks on people or embarrassing them
mischief.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Kiki’s eyes were bright with mischief.
mischief.translation[0].definitions[2].d: damage or harm that is done to someone or to their property
mischief.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The jury cleared him of the charge of criminal mischief.
mischief.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: The children were lively and always up to mischief.
You spend too much time getting into mischief!
Can I trust you to stay our of mischief for half an hour?
Playing football helps keep him out of mischief.
Boys were wandering around, out to cause mischief.
Leo nodded, his eyes shining with mischief.
I remembered him as a giggling boy who was full of mischief.
There was a glint of mischief in her eyes.
